item.description: Recently I read Talia Marcassa’s post Styled Components: To Use or Not to use ? and I was thinking rewrite my all UI components using…
item.content:encoded:
Recently I read Talia Marcassa’s post Styled Components: To Use or Not to use ? and I was thinking rewrite my all UI components using styled-components to make it more structural.

Here are her top highlight words: Furthermore, when you have components that rely on JavaScript for their style, Styled Components gives control of those states back to CSS instead of using a multitude of conditional class names.

That precisely describe what my old codebase looks like. I used OBEM as my css naming style so there are lots of class names with slashes in separated SCSS files.

She pointed out there are four reasons why people like styled-components.

  1. It makes components less bulky For example, instead of using objects and React event handlers to setup a hover state, use styled-component enable us to use CSS to handle UI states.
  2. The ThemeProvider Her team used the ThemeProvider to build a configuration page which allows a user to customize certain stylistic elements like colors.
  3. The CSS function BTW, I also used styled-components’ css function in my blog’s UI components to conditionally render css, which like she said, we no longer had to render conditional class names based on props. In her opinion, this reduces clutter in components as well as maintains a separation of concerns between CSS and JavaScript.
  4. Testing Her team implemented the Jest Styled-Components library for testing in Jest. As she mentioned in her post, It makes testing styled components painless by creating consistent class names and allowing developers to assert specific CSS rules that might be important to the integrity of your app.

She also said there are drawbacks about styled components.

For example, there are certain style rules that her team found hard to apply to styled components e.g. rules that set the placement of an element on a page like margin or display properties.

In conclusion, use styled components will reduce the complexity of your codebase.

It's easy for me to rewrite my blog UI components with the help of styled-components function and JavaScript's template literals.

However, there are a few problems I need to address in the header component. The scroll animation was controlled by its CSS class names, which is not recommended in styled-components. I separated the whole header component to several sub-components like menu components that include desktop version and mobile version, modal component which only functions when mobile menu is open and navbar hamburger component.

This made my code more structural and I could update these sub-components independently in the future.

I also consider adding more features like theme to my blog, which inspired by the Alligator and mouseover dropdown menu to the navbar menu, which is commonly used in modern website.

item.title: My first interview
item.description: There are no details about interview questions in this post. Here I just wanted to focus on how I handle the job rejection. Several days ago…
item.content:encoded:
There are no details about interview questions in this post. Here I just wanted to focus on how I handle the job rejection.

Several days ago I attended my first internship interview. My feeling about the interview wasn't bad in spite of mistakes I had made. However, I didn't pass the interview, which didn't surprise me.

There are probably many reasons for this depressing result, which are omitted in the interview result e-mail. Therefore I need to figure it out myself.

To be honest, after I finished my interview, sitting on the seat of subway and listening to the music playing in the headphone, I was dreaming I passed the interview and got my first internship job. The interviewer made me feel good about myself, and as TechLead said in his video Interview Rejection - How to handle failure (in tech): Don't count on that!

Deep in my heart, I knew I may fail the interview but there were also chance that I could pass it so I grasped the hope. When the result didn't reach your high expectation, you would most likely feel depressed. It is like gambling that you have chance to win and you believe it but you lose the game in the end.

The moment I knew the result, I started doubt my talents and ability. I asked myself that does it make me like a loser? The answer was absolutely not. From the view of statistics, it's common for a senior college student to get rejected when applying his first internship job.

Nobody likes failure. The only thing I could do was learn from it. Katharine wrote these in her post Rejection and the Job Search, which helped me understand job rejection:

Just know that it’s going to happen, and generally, it’s not personal, even though it feels that way. I have hired a lot of coaches over the years and there are often 50 candidates for one position. That means 49 rejections. You are definitely not alone, and you are not in the minority if you are rejected. Learn what you can, change what you should, and then let it go and move on to the next opportunity. You are not defined by your rejection.

She provides several tips:

  1. Don't ask feedback if you don't want to know
  2. Take advantage of what you are learning in the search process
  3. Prepare yourself psychologically for rejection.

She answered the question why I didn't get many interviews as I expect:

If you aren’t getting interviews, it may be your resume, cover letter, or application. Ask an outside neutral party to review your materials to make sure you’re not missing anything. Are you targeting your resume to the specific position or are you sending a generic resume to all openings? Do your research on the employer and the position, and make sure your resume focuses on what each employer needs.

I may get more job rejection in the future, but all I need is one. After many failures, we only need a happy success in the end.

item.title: Reservoir Algorithm
item.description: This is an interesting problem I came across at Leetcode . The question Question: get K random values from N values Straight-forward…
item.content:encoded:
This is an interesting problem I came across at Leetcode.

The question

Question: get K random values from N values

Straight-forward solution

The straight-forward way to retrieve K random values from a list is that use the array to store all possible values and use pseudo-random generator API like rand() in C++ or Math.random() in JavaScript to get K random indexes.

However, when the list length N goes extremely large or couldn't be known beforehand such as the container is a linked list, this simple method fails. To be more precise, once N is large, we couldn't load all data into the memory to retrieve a random value.

var Solution = function(head) {
   this.arr = [];
   let cur = head;
    while(cur){
        this.arr.push(cur.val);
        cur = cur.next;
    }
};

/**
 * Returns a random node's value.
 * @return {number}
 */
Solution.prototype.getRandom = function() {
   return this.arr[Math.floor(Math.random()*this.arr.length)];
};

Reservoir sampling algorithm

Now that we couldn't load all random or couldn't know the size of list, we just need make sure the result satisfy the statistical theory that all values have the same probability of KN\frac{K}{N}NK​.

Algorithm

  1. Choose first K values and put them into the reservoir.
  2. For K+1K+1K+1 th (1-indexed) value, pick it with a probability of KK+1\frac{K}{K+1}K+1K​ , then use it to randomly replace a number in the reservoir.
  3. For K+iK+iK+i th value, pick it with a probability of KK+i\frac{K}{K+i}K+iK​, then use it to randomly replace a number in the reservoir.
  4. repeat until K+iK+iK+i reach N
class Solution {
private:
    ListNode* head;
public:
    /** @param head The linked list's head.
        Note that the head is guaranteed to be not null, so it contains at least one node. */
    Solution(ListNode* head) {
        this->head = head;
    }

    /** Returns a random node's value. */
    int getRandom() {
        int ans = this->head->val;
        ListNode* candidate = this->head->next;
        int cnt = 2;
        while(candidate){
           int j = rand()%cnt;
            if(j==0){
                ans = candidate->val;
            }
            cnt++;
            candidate=candidate->next;
        }
        return ans;
        }
};

Simple proof

For a number XXX in the reservoir, the probability that it continues staying in the reservoir is:

P(Xin current reservoir)=P(Xin previous reservoir)⋅P(Xnot replaced by K+i)=P(Xin previous reservoir)⋅(1−P(Xreplaced by K+i))=KK+i−1⋅(1−KK+i⋅1K)=KK+i−1⋅K+i−1K+i=KK+i\begin {aligned} P(X_{\text{in current reservoir}}) &= P(X_{\text{in previous reservoir}}) \cdot P(X_{\text{not replaced by K+i}}) \\ &= P(X_{\text{in previous reservoir}}) \cdot (1 - P(X_{\text{replaced by K+i}})) \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i-1} \cdot (1 - \frac{K}{K+i} \cdot \frac{1}{K}) \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i-1} \cdot \frac{K+i-1}{K+i} \\ &= \frac{K}{K+i} \end {aligned}P(Xin current reservoir​)​=P(Xin previous reservoir​)⋅P(Xnot replaced by K+i​)=P(Xin previous reservoir​)⋅(1−P(Xreplaced by K+i​))=K+i−1K​⋅(1−K+iK​⋅K1​)=K+i−1K​⋅K+iK+i−1​=K+iK​​

So when K+i=NK+i = NK+i=N, the probability of each number staying in the reservoir is KN\frac{K}{N}NK​.

Q.E.D

item.description: There are several ways to cross origin using vanilla JavaScript. If you are familiar with front-end cross origin techniques, you could skip…
item.content:encoded:
There are several ways to cross origin using vanilla JavaScript. If you are familiar with front-end cross origin techniques, you could skip this post.

What is an origin

If you are familiar with computer networking, you could skip this paragraph.

const url = "https://api.foobar.com/data/users/foo/";
const protocol = "https";
const subDomain = "api";
const domain = "foobra";
const topLevelDomain = "com";
const URI = "/data/users/foo";

For example, https://api.foobar.com and https://www.foobar.com are two different subdomain under the same domain https://*.foobar.com.

CORS

At most time, the pages users access are under https://www.foobar.com. The XMLHttpRequest could only access the resources under the same domain by default.

The Cross-Origin Resource Sharing defines how browser communicates with the server when it has to request resource on another domain. The browser has to add an additional http header parameter Origin. And the server would return response message with Access-Control-Allow-Origin header.

XMLHttpRequest

The modern web browsers (except IE8) all support CORS by default. To use CORS, you just need to pass the absolute URLs in the XMLHttpRequest objects.

XMLHttpRequest can only be used to request URL with the same protocol that under the same domain(Or use absolute URLs to enable CORS)

let xhr = new XMLHttpRequest();
xhr.onreadyStatechange = function(){
  if(xhr.readyState=== 4){
    if((xhr.status>=200 && xhr.status<300) || xhr.status=== 304){
      console.log(xhr.responseText);
    }else{
      console.log(xhr.status);
    }
  }
};
xhr.open("get","https://api.foobar.com/users/foo",true);
xhr.send(null);

Img Ping

This is a one-way cross-origin communication method.

let img = new Image();
img.onload = img.onerror = function(){
  // callback when finished
  console.log("done");
}
img.src= "https://api.foorbar.com/users/foor";

We could set the same handler for event onload and onerror so once the request is completed we could run some code.

The drawback is obvious that it only supports Http get method and we couldn't access the response text.

JSONP

JSON with padding wraps JSON data in a callback function. The JSONP consists of JSON and a callback function.

function handleCallback(response){
  console.log(response);
}

let script = document.createElement("script");
script.src= "https://api.foobar.com/user/foo?callback=handleCallback";
document.body.insertBefore(script,document.body.firstChild);

Using JSONP, we could access the response text. It also supports two-way communication between the browser and the server.

However, when using JSONP, we should make sure the callback function code and the response from other domain is secure.

Another shortcoming is that it's hard to determine whether a request is failed or not.

Comet

Comet is a server-side technique that pushing data to the browser from the server for frequently updated data like living sports matches' scores.

Sever-sent Events(SSE)
let source =new EventSource("https://api.foorbar.com/users");
source.onmessage = function(e){
  let data = e.data;
  // handle data
}
source.close();

Web Sockets

To use web sockets in front-end, you need to make sure your server support it. The protocol that web socket uses starts with ws:// or wss:// as corresponding to https://.

It enables full duplex between the browser and the server and the data packet is rather small compared with Http's.

// must pass absoulte URLs
let socket = new WebSocket('ws://www.foobar.com/users');
socket.onmessage = function(e){
  let data = e.data;
  // handle data
}
socket.send("hello");
let data = {
  name: 'foobar'
};
socket.send(JSON.stringify(data));
socket.close();

item.description: Nowadays almost all websites that have Https URLs enabled are secured with a certificate so users could access these trusted websites in a…
item.content:encoded:
Nowadays almost all websites that have Https URLs enabled are secured with a certificate so users could access these trusted websites in a private connection. Nevertheless, websites with Http identifier URLs are vulnerable to man-in-middle or eavesdropping attacks.

Http: a vulnerable protocol

Http protocol does not defined how to make its messages secured. Therefore, when the client communicates with the server on a Http connection, the messages could be faked or eavesdropped by a third person.

Https: Http over TLS/Http over SSL

Https was formally specified in RFC 2818 in 2000.

The default port of Http/TLS is 443, which is different from http's port number 80.

Conceptually, HTTP/TLS is very simple. Simply use HTTP over TLS precisely as you would use HTTP over TCP.

To enable Https protocol for a website, the website administrator must create a public key certificate for the website server (the actual web server that the website domain pointed to).

To understand how https works, we must understand following several words.

CA: Certificate Authority

The web administrator must create a public key certificate from trusted certificate authority. In other words, website owners should sign up their websites on one of these trusted certificate authorities so they could acquire SSL/TLS certificates from the authority.

The authority certificates that the certificate holder is trusted and is the operator of the web server. Browsers could verify these certificates signed by trusted authorities.

For instance, Let's encrypt provides free and automated service that generates SSL/TLS certificates to websites.

SSL/TLS

The SSL is now deprecated and TLS is commonly used in Https encryption. You may wonder what do the SSL and TLS stand for.

SSL is the shorthand of Secure Socket Layer and TLS is the shorthand for Transport Layer Security. Both of SSL and TLS are cryptographic protocols that provide communication security over the transport layer.

It's hard to locate which layer SSL/TLS using OSI model or TCP/IP model according to an answer on stack-exchange.

The TLS layer wraps the application layer traffic in encryption during transport. You could imagine the TLS stands between the Application layer and the Transport layer.

item.title: From http1 to http3
item.description: If you have learnt computer networking course in the school, you would be familiar with the fact that the Http is an application layer…
item.content:encoded:
If you have learnt computer networking course in the school, you would be familiar with the fact that the Http is an application layer protocol, which is defined in RFC 7230.

The Http often presumes an underlying and reliable transport layer protocol such as TCP(Transmission Control Protocol) which is commonly used for Http.

Http could also be adapted to use unreliable protocols like UDP(User Datagram Protocol).

Http works like a request-response protocol in client-server model. The client could be a web browser which also serves as a user agent that accesses, consumes or display web content. The client submits an Http request to the server. The server provides the resources that the client may request and the server return a response message.

Http/1.0, Http/1.1

Http is a shorthand for Hypertext Transfer Protocol. It's an application layer protocol for WWW(Word Wide Web).

Stateless

Http is stateless. The server does not memorize the total times that the same client requests so it enables the server to support the large-scale concurrent requests. It also bring some risks like DDoS.

A stateless protocol does not require the Http server to retain information or status about each user for duration of multiple requests.

However, some web applications implement states or server side sessions using Http Cookies or tokens generated from the web forms.

Persistent connection: Http/1.0 to Http/1.1

In Http/1.0, the client needs to establish TCP connection with the server by handshake (sending the Http request message when getting the first response message in handshake process). Then the server sending back the requested document to client with Http response message. However, the connection is not persistent so it takes the twice RTT time each time the client requesting a document from the server.

In Http/1.1, the protocol uses persistent connection that enables the client to reuse the same connection to request different documents once these files are stored on the same server.

The Http/1.1 supports persistent connection with pipelining or without pipelining.

When Http/1.1 works without pipelining, the client must send the next request after receiving the response message. You could infer that it takes 1 RTT to access a document in the same server once TCP connection has been established.

The drawback is that the server has to wait for next request after sending the response.

On the contrary, when using Http pipelining technique the client could send multiple Http requests over a TCP connection without waiting for the corresponding responses. In this way, the client could access to all documents on the same server within 1 RTT. To be more precise, t=Tallfilesdownloadtime+RTTt=T_{all files download time} + RTTt=Tallfilesdownloadtime​+RTT.

HTTP/1.1 is a revision of the original HTTP (HTTP/1.0). In HTTP/1.0 a separate connection to the same server is made for every resource request. HTTP/1.1 can reuse a connection multiple times to download images, scripts, stylesheets, etc after the page has been delivered. HTTP/1.1 communications therefore experience less latency as the establishment of TCP connections presents considerable overhead.

Head-of-line blocking

Even using Http pipelining, the head-of-line blocking cannot be avoided. For example, when the number of allowed parallel requests in the browser(client) is used up, the subsequent request must have to wait for the former requests to complete.

Http/2.0

Http/2.0 was published as RFC 7540 in May 2015. It leaves most of Http/1.1's high-level syntax(request message syntax and response message syntax) the same.

Differences: Http/2.0 and Http/1.1

The main difference between Http/2.0 and Http/1.1 is how data is framed and transported between the client and the server.

HTTP/2 allows the server to "push" content, that is, to respond with data for more queries than the client requested. This allows the server to supply data it knows a web browser will need to render a web page, without waiting for the browser to examine the first response, and without the overhead of an additional request cycle

An additional change between Http/2.0 and Http/1.1 is that Http/2.0 uses multiplexing to address the HOL blocking issue but the HOL blocking could still occur at transport layer when using a single TCP connection. For instance, it could occur when the TCP packets are lost or delayed in transmission. And Http/2.0 no longer support Http/1.1's chunked transfer encoding mechanism.

Although the design of HTTP/2 effectively addresses the HTTP-transaction-level head-of-line blocking problem by allowing multiple concurrent HTTP transactions, all those transactions are multiplexed over a single TCP connection, meaning that any packet-level head-of-line blocking of the TCP stream simultaneously blocks all transactions being accessed via that connection. This head-of-line blocking in HTTP/2 is now widely regarded as a design flaw, and much of the effort behind QUIC and HTTP/3 has been devoted to reduce head-of-line blocking issues

The HOL blocking problem is considered as a design flaw of Http/2.0 so take it easy when you use Http/2.0.

Differences: Http/2.0 and SPDY

The SPDY was first developed by the Google that aimed to reduce latency.

From Http/1.1 to SPDY: true request pipelining without FIFO restrictions, message framing mechanism to simplify client and server development, mandatory compression (including headers), priority scheduling, and even bi-directional communication

SPDY gives each action an "Stream ID", meaning there is a single TCP connection channel between the user and the server.

Http/2.0 uses fixed Huffman code-based header compression algorithm instead of SPDY's dynamic stream-based compression.

Encryption

Although Http/2.0 supports both Http URIs and Https URIs, all major clients(web browsers) only implement and support Http/2.0 over TLS (Https).

Http/3.0

It was introduced on September 26, 2019. The Http/3.0 was based on a RFC draft "Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) over QUIC". It's easy to infer that Http/3.0 focuses on QUIC, a transport layer protocol initially developed by Google.

The fact is that at beginning the name was Http-over-QUIC. I think it is time to learn QUIC protocol.

Reference

item.title: DOM Levels
item.description: DOM stands for Document Object Model and BOM stands for Browser Object Model. DOM Level 1 DOM level 1 specification is separated into…
item.content:encoded:
DOM stands for Document Object Model and BOM stands for Browser Object Model.

DOM Level 1

DOM level 1 specification is separated into 2 parts: CORE and HTML.

Core Level 1

Core Level 1 provides a low-level set of fundamental interfaces that could represent any structured document.

Html level 1

Html level 1 provides additional, higher-level interfaces that are used with the fundamental interfaces defined in Core level 1 to provide more convenient view of an HTML document.

Interfaces

Interfaces introduced in DOM1 include, among others, the Document, Node, Attr, Element, and Text interfaces.

DOM Level 2

First released in 2000.

The DOM level 2 contains 6 different specifications: The DOM2 Core, Views, Events, Style, Traversal and Range, DOM2 Html.

The DOM2 Core

The DOM2 core extends the functionality of the DOM1 Core. For instance, the getElementById method was introduced in DOM2 core.

Views

The DOM2 Views allows programs and scripts to access and update the html content (the representation of the document) dynamically. The introduced interfaces are AbstractView and DocumentView.

Events

The DOM2 Events introduces a generic event system to programs and scripts. It includes the concepts of event flow, capture, bubbling, and cancellation. For example, addEventListener and handleEvent are introduced in DOM2 Events methods.

However, it does not include an interface for the keyboard events, which will be dealt with in later versions of the DOM.

Style

The DOM2 CSS allows programs and scripts to access and update the content of style sheets dynamically. So it has interfaces for Style Sheets(CSS2 properties).

Traversal and Range

The DOM2 Traversal and Range allows programs and scripts to traverse and identify a range of content in a document dynamically.

The DOM2 Traversal provides interfaces like NodeIterator and TreeWalker to easily traverse the content of a document.

THe DOM2 Range allows the creation, insertion, modification, and deletion of a range of content in a document, document fragment or attr.

DOM2 Html

The DOM2 Html allows programs and scripts to access and update the structure of a html document.

DOM level 3

First released in 2004.

The DOM3 specification contains 5 different specifications: The DOM3 CORE, Load and Save, Validation, Events and XPath.

DOM3 Core

The DOM3 Core step further on the fundamental of DOM1 and DOM2 Core's functionality.

Load and Save

The DOM3 Load and Save is for dynamic loading content of XML document in a HTML document and serializing a HTML document to a XML document.

Validation

The DOM3 Validation allows programs and scripts to dynamically update the content and the structure of documents while ensuring that the document remains valid, or to ensure that the document becomes valid.

Events

The DOM3 Events is the extension of the DOM2 events specification. It mainly focuses keyboard events and how to handle them.

XPath

The DOM3 XPath provides functionalities to use XPath to access DOM tree.

reference

Fabian Guisset's MDN DOM levels

item.title: MVVM and MVC
item.description: MVC MVC is the shorthand for Model-View-Controller and you may be familar with Java's Spring MVC web framework. It's a useful design…
item.content:encoded:
MVC

MVC is the shorthand for Model-View-Controller and you may be familar with Java's Spring MVC web framework. It's a useful design pattern for modern app development.

Model

Models contains data information. It doesn't call or use View or Controllers directly. It's where we define business logic and ways to represent the data. And it could also contain code for retrieving data from data source like database.

View

View is where users see and interact with the app.

Controller

In fact, Controllers are the bridge between Models and Views. Views call controllers and then controllers call models that required. We could call this process as data binding.

MVVM

As a successor, MVVM is the shorthand for Model-View-ViewModel. As you can see, it removes the Controller and use ViewModel instead. So what is ViewModel?

ViewModel

For instance, we could define a sort of data layer that retrieve the data the View layer requires from Model instead of using the Controller layer to fetch data from Model. To achieve this, we need to create a two-way data-binding between View and ViewModel. And in fact the ViewModel sits below the UI layer.

In Husayn Hakeem's post, he defined that what is a ViewModel:

Responsible for wrapping the model and preparing observable data needed by the view. It also provides hooks for the view to pass events to the model. An important thing to keep in mind is that the View Model is not tied to the view.

One of Stack Overflow's question about MVVM and MVC

The ViewModel ties the data model, or simply the model, to the UI, or views, of the app. It contains the logic with which to manage the data from the model and exposes the data as a set of properties to which the XAML UI, or views, can bind. For example, in a picture sharing app, the ViewModel would expose a list of albums, and for each album expose a list of pictures. The UI is agnostic of where the pictures come from and how they are retrieved. It simply knows of a set of pictures as exposed by the ViewModel and shows them to the user.

Comparations

In Z. Michael Luo's post, he said:

However, the MVC design pattern has its many drawbacks. For one, the use of controllers to manipulate data models creates clutter in the backend. It’s standard for each model in a database to have its own controller, so when an application scales much larger and evolves into an operation with many related models, the amount of controllers used must grow in tandem. This coupled with the natural introduction of new layers of abstraction brought on by most frameworks creates a codebase that becomes very difficult to navigate through.

He noted that:

Another popular method to connect the view to the model is through something un-creatively called a ViewModel. Unlike the controller method, the ViewModel method relies heavily on the frontend of the application.

Unlike the MVC method, the ViewModel isn’t a controller. It instead acts as a binder that binds data between the view and model. Whereas the MVC format is specifically designed to create a separation of concerns between the model and view, the MVVM format with data-binding is designed specifically to allow the view and model to communicate directly with each other.

In short, he said:

It’s simple and allows the view to directly communicate with the backend.

Where could we use MVVM?

The creator of the MVVM pattern himself, John Gossman, said that the overhead for implementing MVVM is “overkill” for simple UI operations (Gossman). Larger applications that use the ViewModel method regularly become incredibly difficult to run. For this reason, the MVVM design pattern is used mostly for single page/function applications on the web.

update: "2020-2-28" comment: migrate to gatsby-remark-embedder

Why? Because user experience matters.

When I developed the Table-of-content component, the scroll event bound with handler like what I did before for the navbar component. However, the answer on stack Overflow talked about the correct way to handle the expensive DOM events like scroll or resize because those events could be triggered many times in short time especially on a mobile device.

The most definitive way to prevent high-rated events (scroll, resize...) from making your site slow or unresponsive is to control how often the event handler is called.

And the answer also refers to David Corbacho's detailed explanation.

David in his post recommended to use debounce, throttle or DOM's native API requestAnimationFrame to control these high-rated events. What makes his post so great is that he uses many codepen embedded code to illustrate those techniques.

These techniques work as a control layer between the event and event handler so they make handler decoupled from the event. We could use these to improve website's performance. But we do not use these techniques to control how often these event are triggered.

For instance, you could see how often the scroll are invoked:

Differences between them

In short:

  • Debounce: invoke the event handler after waiting for a period of time until the last time debounced function(event handler) was invoked. Grouping a sudden burst of events (like keystrokes) into a single one.

  • Throttle: guarantee a constant flow of executions every X milliseconds. Like checking every 200ms your scroll position to trigger a CSS animation.

  • requestAnimationFrame(rAF): a throttle alternative. When your function recalculates and renders elements on screen and you want to guarantee smooth changes or animations. (browser's native API)

A little history

The most obvious difference between html4 and html5 is showed by these tags. The html5 was first released on 28 October,2014 and then has been wildly used in web development since it became a W3C recommendation in 2014.

This purpose of this post is aimed to list all markups that added in html5 so I wouldn't cover up many details on its long history such like conflicts between WHATWG and W3C. However, we need to know that there are two html5 specifications before 2019. One is the html living standard developed by WHATWG as it is never complete and always being updated and improved. Another one is developed by the W3C which is considered as the "snapshot" version of the living standard.

But things have changed on 28 May 2019 when W3C ceded its authority over the DOM and HTML standards to WHATWG. So now there is actually one html5 standard.

W3C html5 vs WHATWG html5

To be honest, I was not familiar with html standards before but it didn't stop me from web development. I may use mix up the html4 markup with html5 markups in practice. However, sometimes I use Chrome's DevTools to inspect the website's elements I may find some markups that I never used before like <hgroup>. Is it a old html4 tag? I didn't know the answer at that moment but now I understand that it is a unique html5 tag in WHATWG html5 standards.

<!-- w3c unique elements -->
<rb/>
<rtc/>
<!-- address is in section grouping content -->
<address>

<!-- WHATWG unique elements -->
<!-- hgroup is supported in all browser -->
<hgroup></hgroup>
<menu></menu>
<slot></slot>
<!-- address is in section content -->
<address>

This image is credit to Mercury999 of wikimedia.

Html5 markups

Comparing to html4, html5 introduces semantic elements and attributes for modern web development. The most common uses of <div> could be replaced with more informative block markup like <header>, <section>, <footer> etc.

Here are all new added elements in html5 or the differences between html5 and html4.01.

<embed/>

<!-- datalist together with the a new list attribute for input can be used to make comboboxes -->

<datalist id="browsers">
 <option value="Safari">

</datalist>
<!-- Defines additional details that the user can view or hide -->
<details/>
<!-- Defines a visible heading for a <details> element -->
<summary/>
<!-- add a visual explanation to an image -->
<figure>
<img/>

<figcaption/>
</figure>

item.title: React Virtual DOM
item.description: React web application is based on React Virtual DOM with a complete lifecycle. Hence, it's important for web developers who use React to…
item.content:encoded:
React web application is based on React Virtual DOM with a complete lifecycle. Hence, it's important for web developers who use React to understand what's React Virtual DOM and how it works.

This post is based on React V16.10.2 so some lifecycle methods may be deprecated.

React Virtual DOM

React virtual DOM support all standard or custom DOM attributes. It's like a React implementation of a browser DOM model but with the cross-browser compatibility. In other words, it's a replica of the real DOM in the memory so React could perform updates to the real DOM as batches in one go.

React implements a browser-independent DOM system for performance and cross-browser compatibility

To understand what React Virtual DOM works, we need to know following things.

  • Differences between the React DOM and the browser DOM
  • React's Lifecyle: When do React DOM's changes apply to the real DOM?
  • React's diffing algorithm: How does React update the browser DOM efficiently?

differences from the vanilla DOM(browser DOM)

  • React DOM use camelCase for all DOM properties and attributes.
  • React Dom must use PascalCase for DOM name.
  • Custom attributes like aria-* should be lowercased.
  • use className to define DOM's CSS class.
  • use dangerouselySetInnerHtml to remind developer when setting inner html.
  • The attribute style accepts an JavaScript object with camelCase names of CSS properties to define inline CSS style.

React lifecycle

This paragraph may involve React component concepts. In React, we could use React lifecycle methods to control component behaviors. We could also know the order React Virtual DOM or React components mounted into the browser DOM from these lifecycle methods.

You could check out this online React lifecycle diagram for a visual reference.

Mount

componentDidMount method is invoked after the component is mounted into the DOM tree so we could perform initialization operations that require DOM in this lifecycle method. For example, we could set up subscriptions or network request for loading data from remote endpoint.

When calling setState in componentDidMount, it will trigger another rendering before the browser updates the screen so this guarantees users won't see the intermediate state. This pattern often causes performance issues and in most cases you should initialize the state in constructor.

Updating

shouldComponentUpdate() is invoked before rendering when new props or state are being received. Defaults to true. This method is not called for the initial render or when forceUpdate() is used.

componentDidUpdate() is invoked immediately after updating occurs. This method is not called for the initial render.This is also a good place to do network requests as long as you compare the current props to previous props (e.g. a network request may not be necessary if the props have not changed).

When you call setState() in componentDidUpdate(), you must wrap it in a condition otherwise you would cause an infinite loop.

Unmounting

In componentWillUnmount method, we could perform necessary cleanup such as removing event listeners (subscriptions) that defined in componentDidMount, canceling network requests etc.

Reconciliation: React diffing algorithm

The state of the art of tree edit algorithm has a complexity in order of O(n^3), which is still too expensive for DOM tree updating. However, React DOM diff algorithm uses several strategies to reduce the time complexity from O(n^3) to O(n).

From the official doc, the algorithm is based on two assumptions:

  1. The same component instances have similar DOM tree structure while instances of two different components have different DOM tree structures.
  2. It's possible to distinguish child elements by their ID/Key prop.

In React the process of applying updating from virtual DOM to actual DOM is called as reconciliation.

Tree diff

When React diff algorithm compares the newest virtual DOM with the previous one and find that the child elements are removed, it would delete that element with its nested child elements in the real DOM. In this way we just traverse the whole DOM tree once to compare all nodes.

DOM elements diff

React DOM elements are like <div> etc.

Elements of different types

Whenever the root elements have different types, React would tear down the element and rebuild the new tree from scratch. Any components below the root will be unmounted first and have their states destroyed.

// old
<div>
  <Counter />
</div>

// new
<span>
  <Counter />
</span>
Elements of the same type

If they are the same type, React will compare their attributes, keep the underlaying DOM node and only update the changed attributes.

// old
<div className="before" title="stuff" style={{color: 'red', fontWeight: 'bold'}} />

// new
<div className="after" title="stuff" style={{color: 'green', fontWeight: 'bold'}} />

After handling the root element, the same process applies to the children.

Component diff

React component are what developers defined. We could use shouldComponentUpdate to decide whether re-rendering the component or not.

Components of different types

The component is considered as a dirty component thus being destroyed and replaced by the new component even two components have similar structures. Sometimes this would lead to performance issues.

Components of the same type

This is what React handles most of time. React needs to update the props of the underlaying component instance to match the new element. This process also recurs on the children.

Children diff

To improve performance, React recommends to use key attribute to distinguish different child elements inside a React DOM element like <li> or a component. Otherwise, simple changing the order of child elements could lead to worse performance.

This helps React match children in the original tree with children in the subsequent tree.

Rendering to the actual DOM

The process of browser rendering UI

The browser has only a single thread for both rendering the UI and performing other javaScript tasks. When it is rendering the DOM, other JavaScript tasks are blocked and vice versa.

Briefly, the UI updates and interactions are handled with the same main thread in the browser. That's why we use WebWorker to handle expensive computing tasks in another browser thread.

A image is worth a thousand words. This is an image from Francesco's post.

Two images from Darrja's post also give a view of how a browser works.

Stack reconciliation

The React DOM diff algorithm in the React with version before v16.0 behaved differently with those after v16.0.

All updates must be completed entirely before returning to main thread and this would lead to poor user experience.

Fiber reconciliation

To solve the rendering performance issue that stack reconciliation has, React re-writes its core algorithm to support rendering asynchronously and the new React is compatible with synchronous code. In addition, the codename of new React after v16.0 is Fiber.

The React official blog posted that when they released React V16.0:

Perhaps the most exciting area we’re working on is async rendering—a strategy for cooperatively scheduling rendering work by periodically yielding execution to the browser. The upshot is that, with async rendering, apps are more responsive because React avoids blocking the main thread.

In this way, updates will be batched in chunks and React will manage the main thread.

  • React reconciliation

  • What’s New in React 16 and Fiber Explanation
  • A cartoon intro to Fiber - React Conf 2017
  • Repaint and Reflow in JavaScript

item.content:encoded:
update: "2020-2-28" comment: migrate to gatsby-remark-embedder

Sometime we need to embed external link to a code sandbox or playground like CodePen to illustrate an idea. However, this is not supported by markdown and gatsby's markdown transformer. To achieve embedding, we need to get the embedding iframe code from the platform or just construct the code by ourselves but the process is tedious.

But there are some platforms that support embedding their application by wrapped inside a <iframe> tag. As far as I know, they are Youtube, Instagram, Twitter,CodePen and etc.

In fact, I have never dive into this aspect before. My opinion about this was that this is just a pleasant way to embed or quote something from other websites and I've never wondered how can we put contents inside a iframe by using url parameters to control its display or function. I never think about it could have its own specification and even a standard format.

The gatsby plugin gatsby-remark-oembed help me embed content from some mainstream platforms that support oEmbed format.

However, soon I realized the plugin wasn't that easy to use for me because by now I've been living in China, a country blocks its people from visiting some great international websites for the sake of national security.

Socks5 Proxy feature

Now I know that it lacks the proxy feature so in order to solve this problem, I just need to fork the repository and add this feature. Let's do it. By reading the source code of gatsby-remark-oembed, I found that the plugin uses axios to request API urls exposed by platforms.

// node_modules/@raae/gatsby-remark-oembed/utils/fetchOembed.js
const axios = require("axios");

const fetchOembed = async endpoint => {
  const response = await axios.get(endpoint.url, {
    params: {
      format: "json",
      ...endpoint.params
    }
  });
  return response.data;
};

module.exports = fetchOembed;

The axios is a promise based http client for browser and node.js and it only supports http/https proxy by setting corresponding http/https agent provided by node.js module http and https.

So is it possible to implement socks5 using node.js built-in module http http agent?🤔 I googled to find whether someone had solved this problem and here comes the enhancement plugin named socks-proxy-agent that implemented socks proxy using http.agent class and other socks client plugin.

Chirs posted an article using-a-socks-proxy-to-make-requests-in-node-js- about this on medium, it helped me to solve the problem directly without knowing its lower details. And there is also an issue about axios socks5 proxy on github.

The solution for gatsby-plugin-oembed is simple. Adding a few lines of code and the problem is solved but has it really been solved?

// modified: node_modules/@raae/gatsby-remark-oembed/utils/fetchOembed.js
const axios = require("axios");
const SocksProxyAgent = require("socks-proxy-agent");

const fetchOembed = async endpoint => {
  // highlight-range{1-4}
  const proxyHost = "127.0.0.1", proxyPort = "9999";
  const proxyOptions = `socks5://${proxyHost}:${proxyPort}`;
  const httpAgent = new SocksProxyAgent(proxyOptions);
  const httpsAgent = httpAgent;
  const response = await axios.get(endpoint.url, {
    params: {
      format: "json",
      ...endpoint.params
    },
    // highlight-start
    httpAgent: httpAgent,
    httpsAgent: httpsAgent
    // highlight-end
  });
  return response.data;
};

module.exports = fetchOembed;

The above snippet is just a workaround for me so it doesn't support custom host and port.

Besides, I have to install the gatsby-plugin-oembed from my own local forked repository in case that each time the files under node_modules are restore to default each time run yarn scripts.

But before I add this proxy feature, I need to check out whether it works or not.

pull request

Here is the pull request and it seems not pass due to some configurations in test files. So I came to twitter to contact the author Benedicte Raae.

item.title: Writing and reading
item.description: Have you calculated how much time you spend on reading or writing each day? Or from a longer time scale like a week or a month even a year…
item.content:encoded:
Have you calculated how much time you spend on reading or writing each day? Or from a longer time scale like a week or a month even a year. ⏳

The answer may surprise you at first if you have not noticed it before. In the past few days, I was busy coding my blog UI though the progress was slow as I need to search for development questions I encountered along the way. Does reading others' posts or answers count as reading activity? In my opinion, it's obviously not. I just read for solving my problems and I didn't dig into some problems.

To find what hindered me from developing I spent one day keeping tracking the time I used on every activity. It turned out that actually I spent 31% of total on reading whereas 18% of total on developing. To find the reason why I spent so many time on reading, I evaluated my reading speed on website. The result looks really bad that my comprehension is not good when my reading speed is fast. That's why I spent most of my time on reading. Because if I want to get better understanding I need to slow down my reading speed.

The fact was that I spent lots of time reading posts on CSS-Tricks then solved my problems in just a few minutes. However, what really matters is that how do we readers know we really understand what the author tries to conveys to us?

As Richard Feynman said,'The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool.'.

Do we really understand the concept better than the author beforehand or do we understand the concept better than ourselves before reading?

Here comes writing. Sometimes I write articles just to help me to estimate what I've learnt and summarize concepts. Writing is not like taking notes or some code snippets. From Scott Hanselman's point, we need consider following things before starting to write.

1.Your post is not that a big of deal.

There are 7.7 billion people in this little planet. The audience of your article is not a big deal even if you hit the headline at some famous website like hackernoon or medium etc.

Besides, I'm writing in English but my native language is Chinese and I am based on China so the target audience of my post is really small (Note there are 1.4 billion people in China). However, I prefer Scott Hanselman's opinion that sometimes we just write posts in order to search it in the future and said "Aha! I had written a post about this topic before.".

2.Comments are written by real human (Not comment robot)

The comments your post received are written by real people. Maybe some of the comment sounds pedantic, mean, rude but remember you are the person take the responsibility to decide how to react to it. In short, that means keep your manner and be polite.

3.Remember why you wrote the post

You do not have to put a lot of energy into writing for people who don't love you or think about you. As a matter of fact, most people read your post and leave comments below are random strangers to you.

But you do need to think about who will read your post and ask yourself so what when you are writing.

Writing post in English could also help me improve my English writing skill. Before I started to write in English I wondered whether do it well. Soon I realized that no people could do anything perfect at first. The only way I would not make any mistakes is that do no take any actions toward my goals.

Michael Jordan said the reason why he succeed was that he failed over and over in his life. His words also motivate me to continue to write.

When you finished your draft, read it in mind and modify it until it sounds fluent and easy to understand.

From my point of view, if I do not know what to write, it means I do not understand what I've read before. If I understand, I could recall it using my own words.

Sometimes if I want to write a how-to post, I need understand each steps and why in order to give readers a better experience. Then try my best to make the post clean and elegant.

In conclusion, if you want to save your time, improve your reading speed. If you want to write, do not be afraid to write and find when you are in your best state to write.

BTW, I'm trying to avoid Chinglish.

Restful API

Here are some dummy code to illustrate restful APIs in front-end development.

const {baseUrl} = require('./config');

}

// You can also use url parameters to filter out URI collection
// like ${baseUrl}/items?id=foo

        id: id,
        }
      });

// modify or update a collection URI by http post method

      data: user

  }

}

Here are some explanations from restful api tutorial.

REST APIs use Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) to address resources. REST API designers should create URIs that convey a REST API’s resource model to its potential client developers. When resources are named well, an API is intuitive and easy to use. If done poorly, that same API can feel difficult to use and understand.

Restful API architecture

If you are familiar with restful API, you could skip this paragraph.

REST stands for representational state transfer and it's an API architecture style for web services. So if you need to follow its specification to implement your own REST APIs.

I think this article is a great reference to understand RESTful APIs though some places are misleading. Hence here I derive my own understanding from it.

  1. uniform interface For example, one type of resource should have only one logical URI in order to fetch it and its related or additional data.

    You should also consider the naming conventions, links formats and data formats. Once all of these follow a certain guideline, it would help developers understand your Restful APIs.

  2. client and server could developed separately On the client you only need to use URIs to locate and fetch the data from the server so both client-side and server-side could be replaced or updated as long as the APIs between them are not altered.

  3. stateless just like http protocol The client-side should take the responsibility to manage the state of web application for users. So in this way server do not store any client context (may store some data for the sake of security)and server will treat all request as new like http protocol.

  4. cacheable Caching data could improve the performance on both client side and server side. Client could have better loading performance. Server could improve its scalability as requests for data have been reduced.

    The caching could be applied on client or server side.

  5. layered system For example, you could store your data on server A, and deploy the restful APIs on server B and authenticate requests on server C. So a request that sent on the client side could pass through many layers along the way to fetch the data.

  6. You could return code like web widget For example, developer could use twitter's API to fetch code for embedded tweet. And I have talk about how to embed UI widget in gatsby in my previous post.

  7. It's ok to violate some of rules It's recommend to follow above constraints to develop RESTful APIs but it's ok to violate some of them because we developers are human, right? The author said that there is no such terms for those APIs that only match part of above constraints.

Restful API pros and cons

pros:

  1. It's easy to implement and it is widely used.

  2. Frontend and backend could develop independently

cons: (Note this is from the view of GraphQL)

  1. over-fetching: download unnecessary data from one API
  2. under-fetching: download part of required data so we need to request many APIs

GraphQL

TLDR: when to use graphQL: rapid product iterations(UI changes rapidly)

I have been using GraphQL since the first day I used gatsby. Comparing it to the restful API standard, it's really powerful that I could fetch anything from my disk as soon as files on my disk have been transformed into types that graphQL plugin could detect by some transformer plugin.

It may bother you that what is a transformer at first but don't worry, Let's dive into the world of GraphQL and we will get to know it.

BTW, both GraphQL API standard along with React are invented & open-sourced by Facebook (Hurrah😆)

GraphQL : graph query language

GraphQL is the abbreviation of graph query language so you could refer it to other query language like SQL which is also an abbreviation of structured query language.

If You are familiar with SQL, you will immediately consider that word graph is a metaphor that stands for some sort of graph structure and you're almost there🎉.

The question is how is it different with other query language. Talk is simple, show me the code.

# graphQL syntax example
# this is a comment
query{
  # an object fool has two attributes name and val
  foo {
    name
    val
  }
}
# this query script will return an object that has name and val

It looks so familiar, doesn't it? The first I saw this syntax what came up in my mind was JSON. BTW, there is no comment in .json file.

{
  "foo":{
    "name": "tizee",
     "val": "1"
  }
}

The common is that they both use key-value to declare their data-format.

a query language specialized for APIs

There have been already many query languages why would we need graphQL?

The answer is simple. On the one hand, there are companies like netflix, coursera, github, twitter that have been using it, which means it does a great work (netflix's open source solution named as Fakor) and it has a great community. On the other hand, this is a query language designed for API. It can be combined with any languages and frameworks once graphQl has been implemented using that language.

You may know the process of loading data on the website. First, you need to

GraphQL server only exposes single endpoint

For example, the github has exposed graphQL API for developers and it also has the RESTful APIs.

# github API v4: graphQL API
#  a single endpoint
https://api.github.com/graphql

# github API v3: RESTful
https://developer.github.com/v3

graphQL application

As it is just a query language, we need to use compiler as translator to tell the computer how to fetch the data from where we store it and what the data we want looks like. In other word, we need to install plugin to run GraphQL.

pros:

  1. GraphQL API enables declarative data fetching

  2. easy to use for front-end developers

cons:

  1. Server-side caching still is a challenge with GraphQL.

  2. Comparing with RESTful APIs, it was quite tedious to implement for backend developers especially they don't understand the schema. In short, it requires backend developers to spend sometime to learn some new frameworks😅.

The SSR is an abbreviation that stands for server side rendering. Most of web developer deal with rendering UI in the frontend which is called client side rendering.

It could boost up your web application by using client side rendering because in this way you have given all page UI rendering work to your client's browser and you just need to fetch the data from the server.

SSR in Gatsby

I didn't know that when in production, Gatsby builds static html files under node.js server that does not have window or document objects. To solve those problems, we need to move those code with window or document to React's componentDidMount function so it guarantees those browser objects available.

If you couldn't move all those code, you could try define your window or document object like this in your module:

// define your own window at the first line of your module file
if (typeof(window) == 'undefined') global.window = new Object();

This was inspired by and the Gatsby issue 309.

during development, react components are only run in the browser where window is defined. When building, Gatsby renders these components on the server where window is not defined. Generally with React the solution to this is only access window in componentDidMount or to check that window exists before accessing it.

Gatsby's official documents also gives FaQ on this topic.

To install node-sass in windows, you must have installed python 2.7 and set the PATH so that the node-gyp could use it to install the node-sass. In my situation, I've installed the python 3.6.5 and add it to the PATH. However, the version of python is not right. To solve this is simple, you could install python 2.7 msi manually or run npm install --global windows-build-tools in terminal with Administrator mode.

If your npm stuck on fetchMetadata or your npm encounters error like rollbackFailedOptional, your probably need to remove the proxy and https-proxy from your npm configuration by using npm config rm proxy and npm config rm https-proxy

item.title: Design my blog
item.description: Why I need to design blog's UI? If I said I'm a frontend developer but in fact I'd never implemented anyone's web UI designs or prototypes…
item.content:encoded:
Why I need to design blog's UI?

If I said I'm a frontend developer but in fact I'd never implemented anyone's web UI designs or prototypes including mine, that would be very ironic.

Before I started to design my blog's UI, I know little about web design. As my major is software engineering in university, the most of I've learnt from courses are something like algorithms, database theory, web developing(most of works is backend developing). I know how to use JavaScript, html, css and web frameworks like vue.js and react, though, it does not help me on how to design a great, marvelous website.

In other words, from the beginning, I lack the design skill which would be a risk for my frontend developing career if I didn't take any actions to improve my design skills especially the skill that implement the web design prototype. However, it's never to late to learn it.

Where to learn it?

There many approaches to learn design e.g watching Youtube tutorials . Another way is to learn web design from others' works on dribble or some great designed website. (I wonder whether I need to buy a design book to learn some basic design theories.)

Stuck,learn,continue and repeat

I skipped reading figma official docs and jumped into youtube channel Dev Ed (Salute to dev ed, wooo!) to learn my first web design class on video Laptop Web UI Design Tutorial For Beginners.

The learning method I took was watching him get a simple web UI design finished in 25 minutes and after watching it I opened figma to design my blog pages.

If I was stuck designing UI prototypes I would came back to his video to see how he design similar UI components. However, soon I found that the UI he designed was a product landing page and how could I learn to design some blog components from a non-blog web design. This time I was totally stuck and began to feel some anxieties from this learning curve.

What I managed to solve this issue is quite simple. I turned to other's blog website to get some inspirations.

When I browsed the gatsby's starter library and find some great starter with elegant design i.e Lennart's gatsby themes leko. I was impressed by his well-designed web page especially the 3D model that can be spun using mouse.

There are many great blog with beautiful illustrations. Here comes some skills I lack one more time. I'd never designed a svg before. When I looked at these art works and used chrome developer tool to dig the secrets behind the beauty I realized I do not know how to use html's <canvas> tag.

The course about web development I learned in the school told me nothing about this tag. Rather than wasting time blaming the out-dated education system nowadays I prefer to take the responsibility myself to learn things that I can't learn in school instead of giving away the responsibilities to others.

Therefore I added illustration design and canvas to my need-to-learn list.

In spite of these things I was not familiar with, I had designed a simple home page since finished watching the video.

It was quite simple comparing to these websites with colorful svg illustrations as background but I was so satisficed about my first design sketch even it was unfinished that I stop to write the part of post you are reading right now.

Illustration style and design my illustrations

There are plenty of illustration styles I could choose from for my web illustration. Personally I prefer flat design because its simplicity and it's modern.

However, it's hard for me to design or draw a character from scratch because my drawing skill is not good right now. For the sake of time, I use some photos as references to draw my illustration design.

Here is the illustration sketch. (We could draw a sketch and take a photo of it then we could send the photo to adobe Illustrator in computer or other vector applications)

Hmm, It doesn't look so bad as I expect. I should have been practicing drawing.

Then exported it to Adobe Illustration and created the vector. It took me about 5 hours to finish it. I must acknowledge that I'm not familiar at Illustrator and the way it works i.e shortcut doesn't follow PhotoShop's.

Here is my first illustration svg.

In spite of some small problems like shadows, I was so satisficed with it. What you haven't seen is that actually I spent 4 days on preparing for this little illustration. In day 1 I searched for basic knowledges of illustration. In day 2 I searched for how to design illustration using Adobe Illustrator in Youtube. In day 3 I searched for how to design flat character illustrations in Youtube. In day 4 I used what I had learnt to draw my sketch and transform it into vector in Illustrator.

I had learnt a lot along the way. Such as how to prepare your illustraion library from this video, or some illustrator tips from examples of flat illustrations.

Here are some good videos or posts helped me through this design.

  • Intro to Adobe Illustrator
  • video:Simple Flat Composition
  • video:Illustrator Tutorial: Travel Flat Illustration Design Process
  • video:Flat Illustration Character Design | Adobe Illustrator Tutorial
  • video:Character Illustration | Illustrator CC tutorial (FLAT DESIGN)
  • video:GIRL CHARACTER Illustration | Illustrator Tutorial (Modern Pop Art)
  • Creating an Illustration Library with Procreate, Illustrator, and Sketch
  • post:6 Techniques to Instantly Transform Flat Designs
  • video:People Illustration Flat Design 🤓 SPEEDART
  • Web Design Speed Art - Illustration Style Website (Illustrator/XD)
  • How to Design and Code a Responsive Illustration Style Website - Part 2

Design UI for different components

Layout UI, navbar UI, header UI, footer UI, post UI, tag UI and so on. There are lots of things I need to deal with. It took me more than 2 weeks to implement all of these UI. But as more UI as I developed, I was getting better on CSS and React js.

In modern web app, they are developed with mobile first principle. The is contrary to my designing order that I designed my desktop version first then the mobile version.

When I started to implement my design, I started to apply this strategy. I wrote layout, then scss code for mobile and at last I wrote desktop version with the help of @media query.

What cost me a lot of time is component animation. It has little relationship with what I've learnt in the school's computer science related courses. However, the smooth animation would make my blog look nicer.

The design demo

For the sake of simplicity, I'll show you some images of design

Desktop design:

Mobile design:

The demo

Here are some screenshots of my blog demo. It was different from my design because I found some flaws in my design when I was coding.

What I've learnt from developing my Blog

The process of developing a website/app is the same as software engineering's.

  1. requirements I want to develop a blog website that supports tag, category, latex, code highlighting and has great animations. In addition, it must could be extended in the future. For this reason, I choose gatsby that based on react to help me generate static pages.

  2. design (Optional as you may just want to create a demo that could work)

  3. logical functions / features This is where magic happens. I need to implement features that I want and some times I could use some gatsby plugins to help me not to reinvent the wheels.

  4. UI Practice makes perfect. I was totally inexperienced with UI development at first until I had to implement the UI by myself instead of using some bootstrap UI components. To implement a design is like building a house just like Chris Blakely said in his post. What I like to do first is implement the html layout, then the basic UI components like tag component and at last I add the logic. But before I started to implement UI, I have to make sure the data available before starting to implement the UI.

  5. Test This is the most time-consuming part of the whole development. I didn't use any javaScript test frameworks like mocha or jest because there is no need for creating test cases for a personal blog. I did test my blog's UI manually using Chrome's dev tool and firefox's dev tool as firefox could show html display layout for both display:flex and display:grid.

  6. Add more features I thought I couldn't stop myself from adding more features to my blog so that I write to-do list for it. Hence, I could implement some of these features in the future.

Thanks for reading

Hopefully this would give you some inspirations on how to design and code your own app/website.

item.title: Compare CommonJS, AMD, ES6
item.description: What is CommonJS, AMD, ES6? Let's make long story short. The implementation of ECMAScript is known as JavaScript, which is supposed to…
item.content:encoded:
What is CommonJS, AMD, ES6?

Let's make long story short. The implementation of ECMAScript is known as JavaScript, which is supposed to only used in browser before, but now it could run outside of browser in a server by a JavaScript runtime called NodeJS based on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine.

However, comparing to the JavaScript browser runtime, the NodeJS runtime could support more modern ECMAScript features(with some syntax sugar) which are may not supported in your browser especially the old IE browser.

The ES6 is an abbreviation of ECMAScript 2015 which introduce many modern features like class definition, object destructing,etc.

You can read the the ECMAScript feature compatibility table to check whether the feature is supported in your current browser.

The modern web development introduce modular system which enables frontend developers to publish their plugins or install other plugin into their project.

Before modular system was introduced into JavaScript, there was no direct way to create a module. You have to copy the code or files you want to reuse from one project to another project which is very tedious. You have to define a module using some tricks e.g closure.

It's easy to import your module when you define your module inside just one file but once you have defined multiple modules in a single file there is no straightforward way to import module on demand. In other words, it's hard to import your modules asynchronously.

So here come modern ways to deal with these JavaScript modules.They are CommonJS, AMD(asynchronous module definition), ECMAScript 2015 module(Native JavaScript module).

Compare

CommonJS

CommonJS is a javaScript module specification which has been implemented by NodeJS and you cannot use CommonJS directly in native JavaScript in browser which requires transpiling. It uses two keywords exports and require to export and import modules.

require is a function and you need to be aware that in JavaScript world the function type is also an Object type. You can actually use typeof to get its type. It's used to import functions from other modules.

exports is an object that used to return the functions inside it.

From the community's discussion, it's recommended to use module.exports instead of exports because "module is a plain JavaScript object with an exports property. exports is a plain JavaScript variable that happens to be set to module.exports in nodeJS". Another reason is because exports and module.exports are pointed to the same object. If you assign exports to something else they are not the same longer. Hence the best practice is to use module.exports to avoid confusion.

You need to watch out for what exports and module.exports point to.

// nodejs runtime
typeof require // => function

// sayHello.js
function SayHello(){
  console.log("Hello");
  return;
}

// es6 arrow function
// CommnJS way to export module
exports = ()=>{
return sayHello();
}
console.log(exports !== module.exports) // => true

// es6 object attribute definition syntax
exports = {
  // sayHello: sayHello()
  sayHello
}
console.log(exports !== module.exports) // => true

// better use module.exports
// NodeJS's way to export module
module.exports = {
  sayHello
}
console.log(exports !== module.exports) // => true

// Other case
module.exports.sayHello = sayHello;
console.log(exports === module.exports) // => true

In the server side, those modules are loaded one by one according to the require order. In this way we could define module per file.

AMD:Ascynchronous module definition

AMD was introduced when CommonJS was not suitable for browsers (it is first implemented by NodeJS that is on server side).

AMD uses keywords define which is a function to load multiple modules asynchronously.

define(['module1', ',module2'], function(module1, module2) {
  // doSomthing
});

// foo.js
define(['moduleA', 'moduleB'], function (moduleA, moduleB) {
    //    methods
    function a(){};    //    private
    function b(){};    //    public


    // public methods
    return {
        b: b,
    }
});

The first parameter is array of module names and the second one is a callback function that called once all modules are loaded.

It's different from the CommonJS mainly because it supports asynchronous module loading. AMD was also a API specification that implemented by Require.js

ESCMAScript 2015 Module ES6 introduce features for importing and exporting modules in both synchronous and asynchronous ways.

It uses keywords export and import to export and import modules. Now we could write something like this:

// a.js
export const name = 'jeff';
export function sayHi() {
  console.log('hi');
}
// b.js
import { name, sayHi } from 'a';

By using import we just bring exported modules into namespace and export makes things public to outside. In other words, they are language-level keywords of which behavior are static.

This enables build analyzer to build dependency map of the project. But we still need use transpliers i.e Babel to translate it to older es5 syntax that old browsers support.

My feelings about JavaScript

On the one hand, I believe I'm lucky not to experience those old days of JavaScript development and just stand on the shoulder of giants (NodeJS and other babel-plugins).

On the other hand, I also believe that it's important to know the past of JavaScript and this would make me understand the JavaScript I used nowadays.

Deep read: some good posts

There are many good posts I think are helpful to understand the concept.

  • CommonJS VS AMD VS RequireJS VS ES6
  • What is amd CommonJs and UMD
  • The state of JavaScript modules

Why git

In my daily life of developing, git is playing an important role. As the fact you may know about, git is a version control tool . It's the first source control tool I've used (Maybe I could try some old tool later).

For guys like us using git everyday, there are some commands we can't live without e.g git commit or configuring in git aliases like git cm.

But this post is not supposed to teach someone who is new to git, it's recommended to know some concepts of git first before continuing. Otherwise, you need to take care of yourself through a learning curve depending how many you know about git.

If you aren't familiar with git commands now, you could read the free online 👉 git pro and try to use git to maintain your docs and code.

Team work commands

On the one hand,commands like git init,git add,git commit,git push,git branch,git merge,git pull,git checkout,git rebase,git tag,git log are quite easy to master once you understand the workflow that comprised of stages or how the timeline/state of repository is changed by those commands.

Here are some basic commands of git.

# help doc
git [command-name] --help

# init
git init

# add file or files
git add [file,...]

# add all files (not including those from .gitignore)
git add -A

# commit with a short message
git commit -m "Your message"

# amend commit, this will overwrite previous commit's message and adding more changes to previous commit
git commit--amend -m "message"


# push and create branch to remote repository
# and set upstream branch for local branch
git push -u [remote-repo-name] [branch-name]

# remove files from git working-tree and not delete them in the desk
git rm -r --cached [some-directory]

# delete local branch
git branch -d [name]

# delete remote branch
git push -d [remote] [remote-branch]

# merge other branch to current branch
git merge [branch-name]

On the other hand, there are some commands we may not use often especially you are not work in a team i.e git diff, git blame, git show.

From my experience, the most time consuming activity about git was find files modified for a particular commit.

Here are snippets from StackOverflow:

# For files changed between a given SHA and your current commit:

git diff --name-only <starting SHA> HEAD

# you want to include changed-but-not-yet-committed files:

git diff --name-only <starting SHA>

# More generally, the following syntax will always tell you which files changed between two commits (specified by their SHAs or other names):
For files changed between a given SHA and your current commit:

git diff --name-only <starting SHA> HEAD

# or if you want to include changed-but-not-yet-committed files:

git diff --name-only <starting SHA>

# More generally, the following syntax will always tell you which files changed between two commits (specified by their SHAs or other names):

git diff --name-only <commit1> <commit2>

# Using the --name-status flag instead of --name-only is handy to get a list of files and see their modification status, such as Added or Modified
